_header: The more I go the further I am behind
_description: ’Tyed with a Line’ — twelve stanzas rhyme royal with refrain.

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
The more I goo the ferther I am behyndethe ferther behynd the nerer
                    my weyes ende…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…Is this ffortune not I or infortunethough I goo louse I tyed
                    am with a lyne
BLAdd29729.Note:
Three stanzas only; ends ‘finis’ (f. 132); heading between
                    first and second stanzas: ‘le dis de lidgate’ (f.
                        131v).
BLAdd29729.Editions:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Lydgate’s ‘Tyed with a Line’ and the Question of
                Halsham.” 
             English Studies
         51 (1970): 527-9: 528.

BLAdd60577.First Lines:
…Euer þe ferther I goo þe ferþer I am
                    behyndeThe ferther I am be hynde þe nere my weyis
                    ende…
BLAdd60577.Last Lines:
…Late men dyspute whether þat ys fortuneNo man soo loose
                    but he is tyede by a lyne
BLAdd60577.Note:
Stanzas 1-3 and 6-8 only; the first preceded by ‘Doctor et
                        instructor monitor petagogus et autor dele iniquitatem meam (f.
                    92).

BLHar2251.First Lines:
The more I go the further I am behyndeThe further behynd the nere
                    the weyes end…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…ffor cristis passioun mavgre false fortuneShal Recleyme vs to
                    his merciable luyne
BLHar2251.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             A Selection from the Minor Poems of Don John Lydgate.
Percy Society
         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 74-7.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 2.832-34.
